justification: “To examine how the brain encodes the anticipation of and receipt of rewards, Knutson and colleagues (2001) developed a response-time task (the Monetary Incentive Delay or MID task).” This task is explicitly introduced as the procedure used to study anticipatory reward responses.

The same paragraph reports that the MID task also isolates activity for the actual receipt of reward: “This approach yielded two core results: reward anticipation increased in ventral striatum while reward receipt increased activation in VMPFC (Knutson et al., 2003).”

“Delgado and colleagues (2000) created a simple card-guessing task in which each trial asks the subject to guess whether an upcoming card will be higher or lower than the number 5. Correct guesses earn a monetary reward whereas incorrect guesses result in a monetary punishment.” This task operationalises processing of monetary rewards versus punishments.

measured_by: single-unit recordings of midbrain dopaminergic neurons
justification: Schultz et al. (1997) “utilized single-unit recordings and measured how midbrain activity changed in response to a cue that predicted a reward,” showing that firing-rate changes indexed reward prediction errors.

measured_by: ventromedial prefrontal cortex (VMPFC) activation in fMRI
justification: “Recent research has suggested that activation within VMPFC encodes different rewards on a common scale in which idiosyncratic subjective values … are matched to neural value signals … within VMPFC (Levy & Glimcher, 2011).” Thus VMPFC BOLD responses serve as the measure of subjective value.
